titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VI: For some weeks past, there has been a small association of Episcopalians who have had the Church Service performed for them every Sunday Morning at the City Hall. I attended there this Morning and heard a Mr Weller preach from Galatians 3.22 “But the scripture hath concluded all under sin, that the promise of faith of Jesus Christ might be given to them that believe.” This is a text for Calvinistic doctrine; and accordingly the preacher dwelt with earnestly upon the universality of Sin, and upon the efficacy of Faith— The Sermon was in a style of cold mediocrity both with regard w to composition and delivery. There were not more than forty persons present more than half of whom were women. I called this Evening at Strother’s Hotel, where I saw Francis Dana— He is on his return from a wandering excursion to the Arkansas territory— I did not even know that he was in this Country. He has made himself a hard life, and when I reflected upon his father and family I felt a melancholy compassion at the sight of
him. His countenance bears the stamp of something more than care. He says he is now going to Boston with a view to make arrangements for remaining and settling in the Arkansas territory. I spent part of the Evening at the President’s where I met Mr George Graham— Mr Hay is ill.

2. V:30.Edward Wyer was here this Morning; and promised to see me again on the 15th. of this Month, but will probably not be a frequent visitor to me hereafter. Mr George W. Erving, some time since our Minister in Spain, called upon me— He was recalled from that mission at his own desire in the year 1819. and has since then been residing chiefly at Paris— In June or July last he came to this Country, arrived at New-York, and has been spending the Summer at Boston. Mr Francis Dana, came to the Office, and I went with him and introduced him to Mr Calhoun the Secretary at War, with whom he wished to have some conversation concerning the Arkansas territory, and a late Treaty with the Cherokees, which has occasioned complaint in that Territory. I called this Evening at Coll. Bomford’s to visit Mr Erving, but he was at the President’s.

3. V:30. Received from Mr Anderson, first Comptroller of the Treasury, a certified copy of the final Settlement of my Account as Minister in Europe, from 1809 to 1817. Five years after my return to this Country. When I returned in 1801. from a Mission of seven years, I was nearly three years in obtaining a Settlement; and in both instances, these delays arose from difficulties, against which it was impossible to guard. From the imperfect manner in which the Accounts of Ministers abroad were at that time kept and adjusted at the Treasury. My own Accounts were kept and transmitted with regularity; but no notice of them was ever taken, and when I returned all the Accounts of three or four successive Missions, through periods of seven and eight years, were to be settled at once. The system has since been improved and is perhaps susceptible of further improvement: to which it will be proper for me to attend— Received despatches from Mr Middleton at St. Petersburg and from Mr Forsyth at Madrid. Mr Middleton gives the substance of a Convention which he has concluded with Sir Charles Bagot under the Mediation of the Emperor Alexander, for carrying into Execution his decision upon the Construction of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent relating to Slaves— Mr. Forsyth’s Letters relate chiefly to the troubles in Spain— I received also a Letter from Mrs Adams in which she mentions a conversation somewhat curious that she has had with General Brown. Her brother is recovering. Evening at the Play— Macbeth and the Rendezvous. The part of Macbeth by Cooper— I was much pleased with the performance— I had seen Cooper only once before, which was at Boston in the part of Othello, on the 21st. of October 1805. I did not then much admire him: though he had already a high reputation. I think him now one of the most pleasing actors I have ever seen— His conception of the character of Macbeth is good, and he knows how to speak the fine passages of Shakespear. An instructive and amusing parallel might be drawn, between the characters of Richard the 3d. and Macbeth— Both murderers from ambition; but of Natures, otherwise as different as possible— Richard crafty, ferocious, unrelenting, incapable of any social affection, and yet of fascinating manners; a fiend incarnate, whose very remorse operates upon him only when asleep and then in mere selfish terror— Macbeth, brave, affectionate to his wife, who is his evil Angel, weak, instigated directly by her; and indirectly by the witches, irresolute, visited by continual compunctions, committing crime upon crime, and always racked with the consciousness of his own guilt. His character is more common in life, than that of Richard. Macbeth is one of the most moral of Shakespear’s plays— It shews the danger and guilt of resort to fortune-telling; as well as the weakness of instigated ambition. Richard’s punishment commences only at the last Scene of the
Play— Macbeth is suffering incessant torture from the moment when his guilt begins. Lady Macbeth, is the terrible sublime of an ambitious woman— Yet her ambition is modified by her sex. She has all the social affections— She loves her husband, while instigating him to the most horrid crimes. She is deterred from stabbing Duncan, herself, because in his sleep he looked like her father— She has given suck, and enjoyed all the sweets of maternal tenderness— She sacrifices all these sympathies to her Ambition. She retains a perfect command of herself while awake— But she walks in her Sleep, and then the agonies of her Soul, are harrowing— Her life sinks under them— The part was performed this Evening by Mrs Lefolle, who reminded me not advantageously of Mrs Siddons—I had seen her twice in this part—23. Decr. 1795 was once. Cooper is growing old, but has a fine person and good voice— Walks the Stage with grace and dignity, and has a correct pronunciation.

4. VI:Mr Force was at my house this Morning— The printing of my pamphlet has now come to that portion of the Manuscript, of which I have no copy, but my first draughts. The revisal of the proof sheets must therefore necessarily be the more cautiously made. With all the care that I can take, errors of the Press will escape. Mr John Mitchell was at the Office concerning his old Accounts. A Mr Duncan also came, and Baron Stackelberg, the Swedish Chargé d’Affaires, who came to inform me that he was going to pass a few days at Baltimore— Between four and five O’Clock, before returning home to dinner I called to see Mr Josiah Meigs who was on the bed of Death. He was seized this day week, immediately after returning early in the morning from Alexandria, where he had passed the Night, with a bilious fever— He was 65 years of age, and had never been sick before. From this circumstance perhaps, he was on his first being taken ill, under the impression that he should not survive— I saw him lying in bed, apparently asleep, with little other indication of disease to the eye, than hard breathing— He died at about eight O’Clock this Evening— It was but last Sunday week that I had seen him ordained the Ruling Elder of the second Presbyterian Church— He was an upright, a benevolent, and learned man— Shortly after we had dined, my Son George came to me in some agitation, and told me that his friend Briggs had seen in the Boston Newspaper that had been brought from my Office, announced the death of his elder brother. He had not known he was ill. I spent an hour of the Evening at Mr Frye’s.

5. VI:Mrs Peyton called this Morning at my house: and Mr Daniel Brent who came to say he was going to pass three or four days at his place in the Country: his brother being there, much indisposed. Mr A. Kerr, the Cashier of the Bank of the Metropolis came to bespeak interest in his favour, as a Candidate for the place of Commissioner of the Land-Office— I received a Note, inviting my attendance, at the funeral of Mr Meigs, as a Pall-holder— Called at the President’s, and met Mr Calhoun there. Thence I went with Mr and Mrs Smith, and attended the funeral of Mr Meigs. He was buried at a new graveyard at the Northern extremity of the City— A short address was delivered, and a prayer made, at the grave, as is usual here, by Mr Baker the Clergyman of the Church to which Mr Meigs belonged. I rode to the burying yard in a Carriage with the rest of the Pall-holders: but returned home in my own. The Columbian Institute, of which Mr Meigs was the President had a special meeting, and voted to walk in procession to his house— I received a Note from Mr Asbury Dickins the Secretary, informing me of this; too late to attend with them— Evening at the Theatre— The Honey Moon, and The Farce of the Dead alive. Cooper performed the part of Duke Aranza in the Play, and Jefferson that of Rolande the woman-hater. This is a very pleasant well-written comedy, compounded out of three
Plays of Shakespear—The taming of the Shrew, Much Ado About Nothing, and Twelfth Night— There is nothing original in it, but the coarse and vulgar humour of Petruchio, is refined and polished into grace and elegance— The Dialogue is spirited and witty; formed upon a deep study of the Style of Shakespear, but modernized and adapted to the colloquial language of the present age. Cooper’s talent for Comedy was as conspicuous in the Duke this Evening, as it had been in Macbeth for Tragedy, on Tuesday.

6. VI.Captain Chase, a Baltimorean, Commander of a privateer now under the flag of the Republic of Colombia, but one of the free-booters who has been for years, alternately under the flags of Buenos-Ayres, Artigas, and Venezuela, preying upon the commerce of almost all Nations, came to the office with his papers, a Commission from the Republic of Colombia, the privateering Ordinance of that Government, and the authenticated list of his ship’s crew— His vessel is at Baltimore, where he entered upon some frivolous pretence, and she has been seized for introducing in her contrary to Law fourteen coloured persons; Slaves— They are entered on his shipping list as Marines, and he applied to me, for an order from the President to dismiss the prosecution and release the vessel. He left his papers at the Office; but I told him his application must be in writing, and that I did not think it even a case in which the President would interfere with the course of judicial proceedings. He said he would apply to his Counsel, Genl. Winder, to draw up from him a written application. Dr Thornton came to me, and said that the members of the Columbian Institute proposed to elect me, as the Successor of Mr Meigs, and asked me if I would accept the appointment— I told him I should have no other objection to it, than my inability to attend suitably to its duties. The Count de Menou, was twice at the Office, upon the case of the owners of the Apollon, against the Collector of St. Mary’s, and upon a small claim of the Governor of the French Colony of Senegal, for the expense of sending an American Seaman, left there, destitute, to Bordeaux. The American Consul at Bordeaux was not authorised to pay the money, and the account has therefore been sent here— John Mitchell came about his request to the President for a resettlement of his Accounts as Agent at Halifax, for the Exchange of Prisoners during the late War. Upon an adjustment of them at the Treasury more than four years since, there was found a balance of more than 12000 dollars due from him, which he now asks the President to strike off by new and extraordinary allowances— I told him it was impossible for me to recommend or sanction them— In my Evening walk I met Mr Frye, who came home and passed an hour with us. Wrote to my wife.

7. VI: I received some days since a Letter from A. Gallatin mentioning that he had seen Russell’s Duplicate, and my Remarks, and asking me to send him some other papers relating to the subject, and certain books— He says he has not determined, whether he will write upon it (for the public) and that if he does it will be with extreme reluctance— I answered his Letter this day, and assured him that there would be no necessity whatever for him to publish anything in this affair. There can be no better proof of the purpose for which the whole machine was set in motion, than that since the facts have been brought out, not one syllable has been said in any one newspaper against Gallatin for his part in the Mississippi Navigation, and fishery proposal, thought it was first offered, and repeated by him, and was neither a favourite of mine, nor the expedient ultimately successful; in securing the interest for which it was advanced— There are Newspapers which still harp upon it; but always, as my measure, and with the view to cast obloquy upon me. In the face of the Evidence they impute it to me: pretend that Bayard finally declared against it, and keep Gallatin wholly out of sight— The whole procedure is a memorable example of artifice by one public man, to ruin
the reputation of another— I received this Evening a Note from Asbury Dickins, Secretary to the Columbian Institute, informing me that I was at their Meeting this day elected their President— Evening at the Theatre— The Wheel of Fortune, with Catherine and Petruchio— The parts of Penruddock and Petruchio by Cooper— I had never before seen either of these Plays. The Wheel of Fortune was written by Cumberland— The part of Penruddock expressly for Kemble; and was one of his most celebrated characters— There is some charm in this Play which has given it continued favour with the Public for nearly thirty years, but it pleases me less than several other of Cumberland’s dramatic pieces— The character of Woodville is at once too base and too brave; and his wife and son are made the instruments as well as the witnesses of his humiliation— A father convicted of villainy, and covered with reproaches by his own Son, in the presence, and with the concurrence of the wife and mother of the parties, is a Spectacle too disgusting to be exhibited upon the Stage, and of no delicate morality— Catherine and Petruchio, is a farce in two Acts, the cream of the Taming of the Shew— Jefferson was duly ridiculous in the unnatural character of Sir David Daw, and laughable in the very natural one of Grumio.

8. VI:Mr Little having returned from his excursion, the public Services were resumed at the Unitarian Church where I attended, and heard him preach. This Morning from Hosea 6.1.2.3. “Come, and let us return unto the Lord: for he hath torn, and he will heal us; he hath smitten, and he will bind us up.— After two days he will revive us: in the third day, he will raise us up, and we shall live in his sight— Then shall we know, if we follow on to know the Lord: his going forth is prepared as the morning; and he shall come unto us as the rain, as the latter and former rain unto the Earth.” The hour of the afternoon service was changed from six to four O’Clock— The text was Philippians 3.9. “And be found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith.”— I have little or no Recollection of the substance or purport of either of these discourses. Mr Little’s manner is not impressive. His Sermons are sensible, but cold; and I on my part am too much absorbed by the world, for due devotion to the Lord’s day. I carry too much of the week into the Sabbath, and too little of the Sabbath into the week. Between the services Dr Thornton called upon me with Mr Von Schmidten, a judge, belonging to the Danish Island of St. Croix, visiting the United States from curiosity and for Instruction.
