div.p:
9. V:30.Mr Homans the chief Clerk of the Navy Department came this morning with a Mr Trask from Gloucester Massachusetts, who is here to solicit, the appointment of Collector at that Port— I advised him to apply at the Treasury Department, under which all the revenue Officers are appointed. Mr. Calhoun likewise called, and a Mr Magruder— Also Mr M’Kenney the Editor of the Washington Republican, who wished to borrow a file of the New York National Advocate, from the Month of May till this time— He afterwards wrote me a note, repeating the request, and asking also the loan of a Report made by Mr Crawford in January 1817. I had not the latter, but sent him a file of the Advocate. The establishment and progress of this Newspaper, forms an epocha in the History of Mr Monroe’s Administration. Mr Crawford’s party was organized before the close of Mr Madison’s— He was a Caucus Candidate in 1816. against Mr Monroe, and had then the address ostensibly to decline opposing Mr Monroe, seeming to sacrifice his own pretensions in his favour, so as to secure a seat in the administration under him, during which he has been incessantly engaged in preparing the way to succeed him. Among the most powerful of his agents have been the Editors of the leading Newspapers;— The National Intelligencer is secured to him by the belief of the Editors
that he will be the successful candidate, and by their dependence upon the printing of Congress. The Richmond Enquirer, because he is a Virginian, and a Slave-holder— The National Advocate of New-York, through Van Buren—the Boston Statesman, and Portland Argus, through William King. the Democratic Press of Philadelphia, because I transferred the printing of the Laws from that paper to the Franklin Gazette, and several other presses in various parts of the Union, upon principles alike selfish and sordid. Most of these papers have signals by which they understand one another; and the signal at Washington is given by the City Gazette, which has been resurrected since Irvine ceased to be its joint Editor, and which from time to time gives notice of the newspapers which are successively induced to join in the train— All this has been going on successfully for some Months past, with little counteraction of any kind, till the Establishment of the Washington Republican. That paper began by a succession of seven numbers addressed to the People of the United States, in which the course of Mr Crawford’s management is very distinctly laid open, and its character vigorously exposed. It has already manifestly disordered the composure of Mr Crawford’s Editorial Phalanx— The Intelligencer has ventured a slight skirmish in his favour— The Advocate, the Boston Statesman, and the Richmond Enquirer, have attacked M’Kenney with personalities, and menaces; the City Gazette has said nothing of him till this day— On Saturday, Elliot acknowledged the receipt of an anonymous communication, styled Instructions to Office Hunters, and refused to print it, without having the name of the author— This day it appeared under the title of Extracts from Instructions to political beginners; headed by the words Help! Help! Help! and then reprinting as “From the Washington Republican of the 7th. instt. Edited by Calhoun and M’Kenney,” a notice in that paper calling for payment of subscriptions— The Instructions profess to be after the manner of Dean Swift, but they are imitations only of his vulgarity and venom without any of his wit. They are infamously scurrilous and abusive, not only upon Mr Calhoun, but upon his Mother in Law— This is Mr Crawford’s mode of defensive warfare— The Article I suppose was written by Richards— Mr G. W. Erving called and spent an hour with me this Evening— He is going to Virginia— Solitary evening walk.

10. V:30.Dr Washington came to my house and informed me that Mr Daniel Brent was ill with a fever at his place in the Country— A Mr Terrell a young man from Virginia, came with recommendations, and applied for an appointment as a member of the Legislative Council in Florida; but there is no vacancy there at present. Dr Thornton, desired me to apply to the President in his behalf for the place of Commissioner General of the Land Office— The President called at the Office of the Department, and I did inform him of the Drs. application, though I knew it would not be successful. The President told me that he had concluded to appoint John M’Lean, now a judge in the State of Ohio. He said that he had determined upon selecting a Western Man, as there was some complaint in that Section of the Union that they had not their share in the distribution of the offices of the Union— He had thought of R. C. Anderson of Kentucky; but that State was said to be in such a humour at this time, that it would have no effect in conciliating them, and it would be prudent if practicable to preserve Ohio from being linked in to their discontents. Mr M’Lean he said had been a firm and friendly member of Congress through the whole of the late War; and was a man of excellent character— I could of course have no objection to this appointment. As the Land-Office is an appendage to the Treasury Department I had supposed the President would delay this appointment until the Secretary of the Treasury could be consulted, but it is impossible that he should be yet informed even of the decease of Mr Meigs. Mr M’Lean I suppose is a friend of Mr Calhoun’s and he has probably suggested the expediency
of filling the place, without delay. Evening at the Theatre— Bertram, and St. Patrick’s day; or the scheming Lieutenant, a farce said to be written by Sheridan. Cooper’s Bertram was the original of which I had seen the copy in Wilson— But he could not reconcile me to the Play, the Style of which is all bombast, and the intrigue vicious. The Play substantially finishes with the fourth Act. The fifth is altogether supernumerary. The farce is full of wit, and overflows with puns.

11. VI:Mr Daniel Brent is dangerously ill with a fever, in the Country— The weather is at high Summer heat, and in a great measure disqualifies me for writing.— I wrote this day only a short Letter to R Rush; and in the Evening walked to Mr Frye’s— I am yet proceeding with the proof Sheets of my pamphlet, the printing of which is nearly completed. In the National Intelligencer yesterday was republished from the Boston Patriot of the 4th. a Letter from Mr Fuller, contradicting the assertion of Floyd, that I had procured him to renew the Call of the House of Representatives for Russell’s Letter, from which Floyd had desisted— These papers I shall include in my publication— The Washington Republican, this day replies to the National Intelligencer’s defence of Mr Crawford, by a long Article, presenting a comparative view of the reductions of expenditure in the War, Navy and Treasury Departments, showing that of them all, the Treasury has the least pretension to boast of its economy. It has also an Article in reply to a very foolish one of the National Advocate, which denied the existence of any opposition to Mr Monroe’s Administration—declared that he had faithfully and zealously discharged his duties as President of the United States, but that he had a private account to settle with the democratic party, which must now go on, by the election of a suitable President for his Successor— The shamelessness with which this principle is advanced that the President, by faithfully performing his duty as Chief Magistrate of the Nation, has violated his allegiance to the party which brought him into power, and that therefore a Successor to him must be chosen who will violate his duty to the whole Nation, by exclusively favouring his own party is characteristic of the electioneering in favour of Mr Crawford.

12. V:30. Morning bath in the Potowmack with George— This is the last week of the Season, that I shall be able to enjoy for this mode of exercise, against which there are here very strong and I believe very unjust prejudices— I swam this morning a full half hour, without touching ground. The two great advantages of the swimming bath are cleanliness and muscular exercise, without being heated— I have never suffered any inconvenience from it, but have always found it conducive to my health— Edward Wyer came, and renewed with great earnestness, the promise he had made me on the 2d. of this month, to see me again on or before the 15th. He told me this day that a person not friendly to me, had told him that he had examined with the strictest Scrutiny my accounts at the Treasury, with the expectation of finding in them something against me; but he had been disappointed— They were perfectly correct, and he was very sorry for it. I asked him who it was, but he declined telling me. I have long believed that this was one of the machines intended to be used against me for electioneering purposes, and that Mr Crawford has had it among the ways and means of his Presidential Canvas.— The person who made this confession to Wyer, I have no doubt was one of Crawford’s subalterns; probably a Treasury Clerk; and Wyer, after telling it to me, to shew how much secret information he could give, was afraid to tell me the name of the person; least he should make enemies to himself— This is one of many incidents shewing the system of Espionage, which Crawford keeps on foot over his Colleagues; and the means, which he is willing to use to depress them— My Accounts were kept five years unsettled upon a cavil without foundation in Law or Justice— I was all but entrapped last winter, into a Report to Congress
which would have given a handle against me; which was prepared at the Treasury and of which it was with the utmost difficulty that I obtained the rectification; and now I have it in proof that there is a person having access to all the Treasury documents, mousing for errors in my accounts upon which to raise a popular clamour against me. Wyer said he would ask the person’s consent to tell me his name; but that is a mere evasion. At the Office the heat of the weather again kept me almost idle. Evening at the Play. Cooper’s last appearance and benefit. Virginius and the Highland Reel. I sat in the Pit. The house was overflowing and the heat suffocating. The Tragedy, is a contrast to Bertram. The Plot well adapted to the Roman History. The characters well drawn with perhaps too much imitation of Shakespear’s Coriolanus and Julius Caesar. The language nervous and unaffected, and the Sentiments, properly Roman— The worst part of the Play is the Catastrophe, by which Virginius strangles the ex-Decemvir Claudius, in the prison, with his own hands, which is revolting. The whole fifth act seems to be superfluous. The Highland Reel is an amusing Comic opera, which I had seen once before, this Season.

13. V:30. Morning bath with George and Briggs; swam about 35 minutes— The heat of the weather made me waste in idleness, the Office hours, and the Evening at home— I am finishing my papers for publication with Remarks upon Floyd’s Letter, which have been written in a desultory manner, as they successively occurred; whereby the manuscript has become such a piece of patchwork, that I gave it to Mr Maury to make out a fair copy of it— I have also employed my Son George to make copies of Mr Floyd’s Letter and some other papers, to be inserted containing proofs of the Value of the fisheries. There was a Mr T. Adams at the Office; applying for an appointment, with a Letter of recommendation from Mr Rodney, the Senator from Delaware— I received also a Letter with a Copy of the late Dr Dwight’s Travels in New-England, and one from Abraham Buford, a person unknown to me, requesting me to send him a copy of my book, to Blacks’ and White’s Post-Office in Virginia—

14. V:30. Bath with George; and Swum 40 minutes. Mr H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana, came, with Mr Clarke Chancellor of the State of Mississippi, and a Mr Magruder, who resides in the State of Maryland— Mr Maury called to ask explanations for copying the paper I had given him; and Force, for copy to be printed. I gave him the last, excepting the remarks upon Floyd’s Letter, and the Introduction— After each proof Sheet has been revised, and struck off, Force sends me one of the printed sheets as corrected, and I began this morning to go over them again, for a second revision, and to form a table of errata. Force says they go twice over every sheet to revise it, at the Office. It is scarcely possible to conceive without knowing by experience how difficult it is to avoid inaccuracies in printing— At the Office, the Count de Menou came to speak again upon the subject of the Apollon, and upon the small claim for the expense of sending a destitute American seaman, from Senegal to Bordeaux— I told him that it would be necessary to have the opinion of the Supreme Court of the United States, in the case of the Apollon; but that I would write to the District Attorney in Georgia, to obtain the decision of the Circuit Court at its next term, so that it may come up to the next Session of the Supreme Court in February. And I thought the claim on account of the Seaman would be allowed. A Mr Adlum came with a subscription paper; he has planted a vineyard in the neighbourhood of Georgetown, and raises wine; but he began only four or five years since; raising a very small quantity; and has been extending the vineyard from year to year. He expects this year to make six or eight Hogsheads, and the President had subscribed his paper to take ten dozen bottles of it. Mr Adlum’s principal reliance seems to be upon the native grapes of this Country; for he
thinks none of the transplanted foreign grapes will bear the scorching heat of our Sun— Evening at the Play— She Stoops to Conquer, with the two wandering Boys. There were scarcely fifty persons in the house, and the performance flagged accordingly. I did not stay to see the second piece, being quite satisfied with having once seen it, this Season— The Theatre is to close next week. The Newspaper war between the presses of Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun waxes, warm. This day, the City Gazette, has three Columns of brevier type, of the foulest abuse upon M’Kenney and upon Mr Calhoun personally—first in a long Editorial Article; and then, in copious Extracts from the National Advocate and Boston Statesman— The exposure already made, and the developement further threatened by the Washington Republican, of Crawford’s practices, and those of his partizans, has thrown them into a paroxysm of rage; and their only attempt to meet these charges hitherto, has been by personal invective and menace. The Republican replies this Evening with firmness and moderation to the National Advocate and Boston Statesman; and reviews his own progress hitherto— If this Press is not soon put down, Mr Crawford has an ordeal to pass through before he reaches the Presidency, which will test his merit and pretensions as well as the character of the Nation— As yet not much notice is taken of the Washington Republican, and its disclosures, excepting by the fury of Crawford’s Presses— His party is so strong; and they have such a ruffian-like manner, of bearing down opposition, that impartial and disinterested persons are intimidated; brow-beating, is among the choicest expedients of his partizans— The progress of this conflict will be a very curious subject of observation; and its result important to the History of the Union.

15. V:45. Bath with George, and swum 45 minutes. Heard Mr Little this morning from 1 John 3.7. “Little children, let no man deceive you: he that doeth righteousness is righteous even as he is righteous.”— And in the afternoon from Jeremiah 13.23. “Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the Leopard his spots? then may ye also do good, that are accustomed to do evil.” This is one of the passages of forcible imagery with which the Scriptures of the old Testament so much abound— The expression is hyperbolical— The form of interrogation impressive— It would seem to countenance the idea that the reformation of evil habits is impossible— It is not in the power of the Ethiopian to change his skin, nor the Leopard his spots—But would it not be absurd to reprove them, for what they cannot change? or to exhort them to what they are unable to effect? This is a difficulty in the text which Mr Little attempted to get over; but which is perplexing— I received yesterday a Letter from Henry Meigs at Perth-Amboy, requesting me to afford his Mother my good advice for the arrangement of his father’s Affairs. I called at her house this Evening, and tendered to her any aid, or service, of which she might stand in need, and which it would be in my power to yield— She said there was some difficulty in the Settlement of an old account which had given him great trouble, for want of a voucher lost or mislaid— It had been for a considerable balance, and had given him so much vexation since the last Spring, when under what is called Mr Cocke’s stop Law, they stopped at the Treasury the payment of his Salary on the ground of his being in arrears.— The vouchers however had all been found with the exception of one, for an item of 300 dollars, and the person who gave that voucher had been written to, for a copy of it, or for a new one— If I could get the settlement of this account expedited, she said it would remove the only remaining obstacle to the adjustment of his concerns— The elder Mrs Calhoun was there. Mrs Meigs’s youngest Son, from Baltimore, and the wife of another Son residing at Philadelphia; who goes to-morrow.

16. V:30. Bath with George and swam 50 minutes. I have found that in this practice, I could add about five minutes every day to the time I could swim without too much exhaustion. At first I was wearied in 20 minutes— I found no inconvenience from swimming this day 50. I should have begun this habit earlier in life— Mr Robert Clarke brought me a Bill from the Washington Asylum for the expense of maintenance, and burial of Rachael a black woman who had belonged to Mr T. B. Johnson. She died the 20th. of August— Mr Ironside came to my house, to say that Mr Daniel Brent had been dangerously ill, but was believed to be now upon the recovery. Mr Anderson the Comptroller called at my Office concerning the answer to be given to the Swedish Consul upon a claim that the extra foreign duties on a Cargo of other than Norwegian produce, imported in a Norwegian Vessel, should be remitted; on the ground that the like privilege is by the Norwegian ordinance, allowed to us in the Ports of Norway. An answer for the Comptroller had been written in his office, admitting this claim and promising the remission, but I told him it was not authorised by the law, and he concurred with me in opinion. I spoke to him of the Count de Menou’s claim for the French Governor of Senegal, which he thought might be admitted and paid— I received a second Letter from the Danish Minister Pedersen claiming the delivery of a Slave, belonging to the Danish Island of St. Croix, who escaped, by getting on board of an American vessel, unknown to the Captain until she was 150. miles at Sea, and was brought into New York— There between his claim of Liberty supported by the manumission Society; the claim for his delivery up in behalf of his owner, and the Police Laws of the State of New-York against vagrants, he has already been taken from the custody of the Captain, carried before a Magistrate by Habeas-Corpus, and remanded to confinement under the vagrant act— There is difficulty in determining how to proceed in the case— I had upon Pederson’s former Letter proposed to the President to take the opinion of the Attorney General; but Mr Wirt has been absent till within these few days— Received a Letter from my wife, who has been unwell, but is recovering— Evening cool.

17. VI. Bath with George. The last for the Season— Morning cold and gusty. Mr Newell called upon me concerning the Affairs of Mrs Meigs.— Mr Meigs had a small landed Estate in Georgia which there is now an opportunity of disposing of, but as Mr Newell thinks not so advantageously as it may be hereafter.— He advised her to wait for the return of Mr Forsyth; with which I concurred— Mr Newell is a Georgian employed in the Land-office. Mrs Forsyth is daughter of Mr. Meigs. I received a Note from the President calling a Meeting of the members of the Administration, at one O’Clock this day, with Letters from Lieutenant Gregory, commander of the U.S. Schooner Grampus, to the Secretary of the Navy; containing an account of the capture by him of the Spanish privateer Panchita or Palmyra, from Porto-Rico. 21 [symbols][October] I attended at the President’s accordingly. Mr. Calhoun and Mr Wirt were also there, being the only other members of the Administration in the City. The Letters of Lieutenant Gregory had been read by us all; and the President proposed the question whether any measure of the administration would be necessary in consequence of this capture. Mr Calhoun said he thought that from Lieutenant Gregory’s Letter, the justification for the capture of the Spanish privateer was rather slender; but I observed that according to my recollection of the Law, it had been strictly legal— I then recurred to the Act of Congress of 3. March 1819 “to protect the Commerce of the United States and punish the Crime of Piracy”; continued by the Act of 15 May 1820. I read the second and third Sections of the Act— The capture was made under instructions given by virtue of the second Section— It authorizes the President to issue Instructions to our Naval Officers to capture and send in any armed vessel which shall have attempted, or
committed any piratical aggression, upon any vessel of the United States, or any other vessel— Mr Calhoun enquired whether any aggression by a vessel bearing a lawful commission, could be denominated piratical. I thought there was no doubt it could; and the third Section of the Act under Consideration, which authorizes merchant vessels to defend themselves against aggressions of any vessel other than public armed vessels, taken in connection with the second, which makes no such distinction, shews that the Act itself considers piratical aggressions, as liable to be committed by public armed vessels as well as others. Mr Calhoun understood them in the same manner— The President sent to the Navy Department for a copy of the Instructions given under the Act of 3. March 1819: and when they were procured, it was found that although they fell rather short of the authority given by the act, they yet fully justified the capture of the Panchita, by Lieutenant Gregory— I mentioned the discussions at the Cabinet Meeting when these Instructions were to be prepared, which were recollected both by the President and Mr Calhoun (see this Diary Vol. 6. for 16 and 18. March 1819.)— I gave Mr Wirt, the Letter from Mr Pedersen the Danish Minister claiming the delivery of the fugitive slave from St. Croix requesting his written opinion upon two points—first whether the President has Constitutional authority to deliver up the Slave, and secondly, if he has in what manner it can be legally carried into effect— Evening at the Theatre, after calling on Mr Calhoun, who went with me. It was Mr and Mrs Jefferson’s benefit— Mrs Inchbald’s Comedy of Every one has his fault and the Melo-drama, of Robinson Crusoe; or the bold Buccaneers— In the interval between the two a Song, called Sammy Sugar Plumb and Polly Chitterlings, which was encored and repeated. I saw the Play at Philadelphia, in the Summer of 1794. much better than now— The part of Lady Eleanor Irwin was then performed by Mrs Whitlocke, a Sister of Mrs Siddons, with a Considerable portion of her Powers; and that of Lord Norland by Fennell— These characters were now cast upon Mrs. Lefolle, and Hathwell, both indifferent actors, and the play was quite another thing. The part of Jefferson himself, Solus, was well performed, but it is a very subordinate character, and merely ridiculous, with little wit or humour— Mr John Law, who was with me, in the same box, remarked upon the character of Harmony in this Play, who reconciles to each other several of the others, from marked dislikes and prepossessions, by telling each of them that he had heard the other speak well of him— He said he had repeatedly made the experiment; and never knew it to fail. The practice would however require some modification, from regard to truth— Law told me that he and some other Citizens of this place, friends of the Drama, had given the Players a parting dinner, and drank them all except Jefferson under the table— The House was well filled.

18. VI—Mr George Storer Bulfinch called this morning at my house to renew an application which he has repeatedly made before for an appointment as a Clerk in the Department of State— He left with me a recommendation signed by seven members of Congress dated in May last and which he had then brought to me— He now desired me to keep it on my private file, to be recurred to, in case, of any opportunity for an appointment. At the Office, I received a Letter from Mr Ware and Mr Overton, the Commissioners for Land titles in Florida; and one from Mr White their Secretary; shewing the want of the documents which were carried to the Havanna; which had been stipulated to be delivered up; but which have been repeatedly refused by the late Governor Mahy— Copies of these papers must be forwarded to Mr Forsyth at Madrid. I have been for some time engaged, in reading the Reports of the Commissioners under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent. That of Mr Van Ness the American Commissioner is short; but that of the British Commissioner Barclay, fills near 400 pages of a Folio Volume. I received last Evening a Letter
from Alexander Wilson, representing himself to be in great distress; and requesting an interview with me, to explain to me, his motive for writing to me— I answered his Letter this day, appointing to-morrow morning 11. O’Clock at my house, to see him— Evening walk alone.

19. V:15.Alexander Wilson came this morning to my house, according to appointment. I found it was the late Othello and Alexander the Great of the Theatre— His motive for asking the interview, was to tell me that he was in a great want of money, and to ask if I would accommodate him with a loan— He said he had not derived a dollar of profit from his performances here; and although engaged to perform at Baltimore in November, he knew not what to do with himself in the interval—and he shewed me a very urgent Letter from his wife, calling upon him for money. I told him that I felt for his situation, but could not lend him money— With the exception of my having seen him on the Stage, he was a stranger to me, and I did not know exactly why he had addressed himself to me. He acknowledged that he had consulted nothing but his wants, and requested me to keep his application to me secret; which I promised. I almost blame myself for refusing him; but I was quite blaming myself for a foolish loan very recently made, of which I shall never see the return— A man who has the ability must sometimes lend money, to bestow it; well knowing that it will never be repaid. But he must also sometimes withhold his hand— I called at the Comptroller Anderson’s Office, about the settlement of the late Mr Meig’s Account. There was a single document wanted— A receipt or certificate of General Rector, for a Sum of 300. dollars. The papers contained evidence to raise a presumption, and which I thought might with safety be admitted as vouchers. He said he would admit them if possible; and he agreed to allow the payment of the claim of the French Governor of Senegal. The Count de Menou called at the Office, and told me he should leave the City to-morrow; to pass some days at Baltimore and afterwards at Philadelphia— I told him that I should write to the district Attorney of the United States in Georgia, to have the case of the Apollon sent up to the next Session of the Supreme Court; and desired him to write me a letter asking payment of the claim for sending the Seaman to Bordeaux; upon which, it would be paid— Dined with Mr and Mrs Smith, Briggs and George, at Mr Frye’s— George and Briggs went in the Evening to the Play, which was for Mrs. Anderson’s and T. Jefferson’s benefit— I did not go— I answered Henry Meigs’s Letter—

20. V:15.Dr Thornton came in this morning to give me his opinion upon the appointment of Mr M’Lean of Ohio, as Commissioner of the Land-Office— The Dr thinks it very absurd to go several hundred Miles into the States, to seek public Officers which might be as well filled, by inhabitants of the district of Columbia— He thinks they have an equitable right to be preferred to all others. Mr. T. Bulfinch junr came to solicit an appointment of Clerk in the Department of State; though he said he did not wish to interfere with the prospects of his brother. But he thought there might be room for both. I told him candidly that was impossible— Major Young whose health has been infirm for many Months, has been very ill these three or four days, and yesterday there was a rumour abroad that he was dead— The first that I knew of it, was by a Letter from W. Brown of Georgetown—asking for his place— But the report was premature. The President of the Marine Insurance company of Alexandria, came to enquire concerning the character of Mr John Connell, for which he had been referred to me— The Company have claims upon the French Government, and as Connell is employed as the Agent of certain Insurance companies for similar claims, the company at Alexandria wished some testimonial to his character to determine whether they should repose the same trust in him— I spoke of Mr Connell, as I thought, and recommended him as a man perfectly trusty. I knew none in whom I should place more entire
confidence; though he has been unfortunate in business— Mr Francis Dana came to tell me, that he had now finished his business here, and was going tomorrow for Boston. The President called at the Office, and told me he should go to-morrow for a few days to his place in Loudoun County. I received yesterday a Letter from Mr William Sturgis at Boston, with a small pamphlet of observations upon the Russian claims in the pacific Ocean; and upon my correspondence with the Russian Minister Poletica, on that subject last Spring. It is to be published in the next number of the North American Review; but has also been separately printed— This day I received despatches from A. Gallatin; one, an argument in support of the ground which he took in correspondence with the French Government, in the case of the Apollon; and one, in which he manifests a little disappointment at the conclusion of the Convention with France. He thinks we have conceded more to France than was necessary, and yet doubts if the principal Separate Article, will be ratified by France. There is personal feeling betrayed in this despatch, and disappointment that the Convention was not concluded by him. This afternoon I attended the funeral at Georgetown of Mrs Macomb, wife of General Macomb, who died of a childbed fever— Mr Calhoun took me there in his carriage; and after the funeral brought me home— Mr H. Johnson, the Senator from Louisiana, rode with us, and went home with him.

21. V:30. The President went to his seat at Oakhill, near Aldie, Loudoun County, Virginia— Mr. Force came and took the last Sheet of my proposed pamphlet, with the title-page, table of Contents and Errata: all of which I have prepared; and which have occupied so fully since the first of July all the time that I could spare from the indispensable duties of my Office, that my diary has in the interval been running into long arrears— Between the 26th. and 29th. of August having finished the controversy with Russell, I resumed my diary, and brought it up to the 6th. of July—but when Mr Floyd took the field under a new mask, with a desperate lunge at me under colour of neutrality, I thought it necessary to strip the mask from him too. The Editorial Article of the Kentucky Argus is by or from Clay; and as he fights under cover, I have adapted the defence to the attack— Force says the book will be published on Monday. I now dismiss it to its fate, and this day took up again my Diary at the 6th. of July— Evening at the Theatre. The Season closed with the Cure for the Heart Ache; and the Melo-drama of the Russian Boy. I had seen the Play, at Providence the 3d. of September 1818. not quite so well performed as now— The most comical parts in it, are old and young Rapid, Miss Vortex, and the speech-making Nabob. The Melo-drama is from a Story by Mrs Opie; which I have not read. The dramatic Corps proceed hence, to Baltimore, where they are to open their campaign next week— The Washington Republican, and City Gazette—War and Treasury Departments are yet in deadly conflict; but with such unequal force; all Reason, Argument, and demonstration on one side, and all scurrility and Billingsgate on the other, that the National Intelligencer has been compelled to step in to the relief of the Treasury— The Editors by some shuffling and equivocating paragraphs, professing the intention, not to meddle with the controversy— And now by a formal communication signed “a Near Observer,” almost avowedly from the Treasury, and supposed to be written by Asbury Dickins, a favourite Clerk in that Department— This is the only attempt hitherto at answering argumentatively the Washington Republican— But Noah—the Editor of the New-York, National Advocate has discovered that some of M’Kenney’s printed proposals for publishing his paper, were transmitted franked, by the Paymaster and Adjutant General, and charges this, as a violation of the franking privilege, and a fraud upon the Post-Office— M’Kenney this day admits that some of his proposals were thus transmitted, with a sort of farewell Letter to persons with whom he had corresponded as Indian Agent, privileged to frank; but says that as soon as this was made known to Mr Calhoun, he disapproved it, and directed its discontinuance. The City Gazette makes a great
outcry about this incident, which is of more importance as it shews the intimacy between the War-Office, and the Washington Republican, than in any other light. Mr Frye went with us this Evening to the Theatre.

22. VII. Called this morning before Church to see Major Young, and found him as he said much better than he had been; but his breath was short, and his countenance emaciated and haggard. He said his physicians hardly understood his case— It is probably dropsy in the Chest— Heard Mr Little, in the forenoon from Matthew 27.3.4.5. “Then Judas, which had betrayed him, when he saw that he was condemned, repented himself, and brought again the thirty pieces of silver, to the chief priests and elders,—Saying I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood. And they said, What is that to us? see thou to that— And he cast down the pieces of silver in the temple, and departed, and went and hanged himself.” The character of Judas Iscariot is an easy and a copious subject to handle for moral doctrine— Treachery for money— Treachery by a kiss.—hypocritical economy and concern for the poor; tardy and fruitless remorse, self condemnation and suicide, constitute the principal features and incidents of this character— Judas was not of the Class of hardened villains— His moral sense was strong; as is the case generally with hypocrites. He could not bear life itself under the reproaches of his own conscience— His original vice was avarice, and it made him a hypocrite, a thief, a traitor, and a self-murderer— What could have induced such a man to become a follower of Jesus? Why was he charged with the bag? When Jesus at the supper table, told him, in an answer to his enquiry that he would be the traitor, why did he make no reply? When Peter was told, that in spite of all his protestations he would that same night deny his Lord; he still protested that he would not— Judas when told that he would be the traitor, said nothing. Peter was honest; conscious of his own intentions, and presumptuous of his own firmness. Judas too was conscious, and had not the courage to deny what he knew to be true— Mr Little viewed this subject in other lights; but treachery and desertion are subjects upon which at this period I have reason to reflect with particular interest. The afternoon text was from 1. Kings 18.21. “And Elijah came unto all the people, and said, How long halt yet between two opinions? If the Lord be God, follow him: but if Baal, then follow him. And the people answered him not a word”— George was unwell. I wrote this Evening to my father.

23. V:30. A Mr Charles Jones came this morning and applied for the appointment of Consul at Demarara. Mr George Hay called and mentioned certain recent publications respecting the notorious Newburgh Letters, circulated in March 1783. instigating the army to mutiny— The author of them has always been supposed to be John Armstrong, a man variously distinguished in our later History, who has never explicitly avowed or disowned them publicly; but who as William Lee told me printed them while at Paris in a pamphlet, and distributed them among his acquaintance, as his own— He then gave one of them to Lee himself— Judge William Johnson, in his recently published sketches of the Life of General Greene, calls in question Armstrong’s authorship of these Letters, as far beyond his ability, and attributes them to Gouverneur Morris— Since then, and within these few days a paragraph has been current in the Newspapers seemingly though not avowedly from Armstrong himself, introducing a Letter, purporting to have been written by President Washington in 1793, to Armstrong. Mr Hay asked me if I had seen it this morning in the Alexandria Herald. I had not seen that paper, but had seen it lately in other Newspapers. Mr Hay asked if I had ever heard of that Letter before. I had heard there was such a
Letter but have no distinct recollection when or where. The Letter purports to have been written 23. February 1793. and is now stated, on belief, as having been first published in 1803. It is a declaratory certificate that in writing his address to the army on the occasion of the Newburgh Letters General Washington did not regard Mr Armstrong as the author of those Letters, and further that he had since had reason for believing that the object of the author, was just, honourable, and friendly to the Country, although the means suggested by him were certainly liable to misunderstanding and abuse— And the reason alledged for giving this certificate are, the belief that there might be times and occasions, when the writer’s opinion of the anonymous Letters, as delivered to the army in 1783. might be turned to some personal and malignant purpose— Hay said he believed that this Letter was a forgery— It was impossible that General Washington should even have written such a Letter, or ever have certified that he had reason to believe that the object of the incendiary of Newburgh was just, honourable and friendly to the Country. I told Hay I was afraid that he had: as it was unquestionable that Mr Jefferson had nominated the incendiary to foreign Missions of the highest trust— As a member of the Senate, I had voted against that nomination, alledging distinctly as my reason that Mr Armstrong was known to be the author of the Newburgh Letters— Others voted against him for other reasons—no one alledged that; and the nomination was confirmed by the casting vote of the Vice-President— I told Hay that I still believed Armstrong to be the author of the Newburgh Letters— That I believed it impossible that their object should have been just, honourable or friendly to the Country— That I believed Armstrong to be one of the ablest writers and most unprincipled public men, that this Country had ever produced— And that General Washington, Mr Jefferson, MrMadison, George Clinton, the Senate of the United States, and the Legislature of New-York, all of whom had at various times, and in diverse manners concurred in appointing him to great public trusts, had indulgently overlooked the depravity of the Newburgh Letters, or attributed them to a youthful excess of an ambitious Spirit; afterwards chastised by experience into honour and honesty— I had myself been willing for some time to cherish such hopes; but Mr Armstrong’s public life has been but too clearly marked with the stamp of the Newburgh Letters— And I thought Judge Johnson’s suggestion that they were written by Governeur Morris, very feebly supported by his evidence— Hay said he thought so too— But he could not believe General Washington had ever written this Letter; and he mentioned reasons for disbelieving it— That no mention of it was made in Marshall’s Life of him— That his signature as printed in the Newspaper was not like that habitually used by the General, and that it was impossible he should have entertained the sentiment expressed in it— Mr Hay has I think particular motives for these enquiries. The President returned this day from Loudoun. I received despatches from Mr Rush at London, and from Mr Forsyth at Madrid— Mr Rush sends a copy of the Convention lately concluded by Mr. Middleton at St. Petersburg— Mr Forsyth gives an account of the convulsive political State of Spain— Mr Calhoun called at the Office and I gave him Rush’s despatch, to take him with him. Force called with the last revised sheet of my pamphlet, the publication of which will be yet some days delayed— I spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s—

24— VI:30.Mr Hadfield called at my house— He wished to send to Mr Rush a Power of Attorney, to recover for him a Legacy of £1500 Sterling left him by Lady Sarah Lyttelton: and asked me if I thought Mr Rush would undertake it, and if I would forward the Letter— This I readily promised and said I had no reason to believe Mr Rush would object to rendering him this service; though it would of course be in his private capacity, unconnected with his official duties. I told him how
he must have his Power authenticated and he will bring it to me to be forwarded— Mr Calhoun brought me back Mr Rush’s despatch, and said there had been a good deal of parade, in the transaction of this business at St. Petersburg; an observation, which disclosed a feeling not exactly suited to the occasion— The convention proposes, that eventually an average value, should be paid for the Slaves carried away. Mr Calhoun said if that meant one average value for each Slave upon the whole number, it would not be satisfactory, nor just— The price of Slaves increasing from North to South; the sufferers in Maryland and Virginia would be overpaid, while those in Carolina, Georgia, and Louisiana would not be indemnified. I said I did not suppose it would be necessary to strike one and the same average for the whole, but a separate one perhaps for each State where the losses had been sustained— Mr E. J. Lee Clerk of the U.S. Circuit Court at Alexandria, called concerning a claim for making returns called for by a Resolution of the Senate; but for which they made no provision to pay for the charge of making the returns— Mr Brent had thought there was some fund from which the claim could be paid, and had made some enquiries at the Treasury to ascertain. But as he is yet confined by a fever at his house in the Country I desired Mr Lee to wait for an answer, till his return— Johnson Hellen came from Rockville to pay us a short visit. At the Office Major Roberdeau called, and told me he was going to New-York to see W. Duane, who is going to the Republic of Colombia. Duane and Meade, have acted as the Administrators of the late Chargé d’Affaires from Colombia, Manuel Torres: and Duane has written to ask that a manuscript map, which Torres had lent me, of the water communication between the Atlantic and South-Seas, at the Isthmus of Panama should be returned to him— I had sent it to Major Roberdeau at the War-Office to be copied, and he now returned it, a copy having been taken— I desired the Major to take it to Mr Duane. I sent Duane some time since a Passport, which he had requested, and have now received from him a Letter offering his services in the Republic of Colombia— Duane has sold his establishment of the Aurora Newspaper at the Philadelphia, and is going to Colombia, as Agent for certain private claims of merchants in Philadelphia— Mr Bailey was at the Office, having returned from his excursion to New-England— I was at the President’s, and took to him Duane’s Letter with his offer of Services— I spoke to the President of the projected Missions to South America, Congress having made appropriations, at their last Session for five Ministers Plenipotentiary to Mexico, Colombia, Buenos-Ayres, Chili and Peru— None have yet been appointed; and the Senate manifested a disposition to question the Constitutional Power of the President, to make appointments in the recess. None of the Appointments have been made, and although the President has no doubt of his power, he wishes in the present temper of the Senate to avoid any unnecessary collisions with them— I asked the President if Mr G. W. Erving had signified to him a wish to be employed in any of those missions, or otherwise. He said he had not, and added that he thought Mr Erving, considering the business of his individual connection with this Country, had already received as much favour from the Executive of the U.S. as fell to his share. He was barely a Citizen of the United States— He had no settled residence in this Country, and scarcely ever had lived in it more than a few Months at a time— A public Minister of this Union should have some hold upon the Country, and obtain testimony of Confidence from other quarters besides the Executive of the general Government. With all these opinions I concurred; and said that Mr Erving had not intimated to me, any desire to be employed; nor had I any other reasons for presuming he had such desire, than his having come to this Country at this time— But as I
was and always had been upon friendly terms with Mr Erving, I thought it proper to mention his name to the President, as one of the persons to be considered in fixing upon the appointments for South America—The President gave me a written paper containing his views upon certain allowances to Ministers of the United States abroad— He has allowed Mr Clay’s extraordinary claim for half an outfit upon occasion of his going to England for the Negotiation of the Commercial Convention of 1815. and Mr Armstrong had now brought forward a similar Supplementary claim for a whole additional outfit, for extra-services alledged to have been performed by him while he was Minister in France— The President asked me to look over the paper he had written, and to inform him if it contained any erroneous statement or any material omission of fact— I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and finally took up my Note there. Evening at Chess with W. S. Smith.

25. VI:Mr Bailey called this morning at my house, and shewed me Letters which he had received from Seth Hunt, Dr Judson and Captain O’Brien. That from Hunt requested information upon various enquiries, of facts, which he wishes to shew in Evidence upon the trial of the Indictment against him for a libel upon Jonathan Russell. Some of them are facts to be proved only by the records in the Department. Others are personally known to me— I desired Mr Bailey to answer Mr Hunt; that as his enquiries were made with a view to obtain judicial testimony, I thought it could be furnished only upon a judicial Summons, and in a manner by which the other party to the cause should enjoy all his privileges of attendance and Cross-examination— The Letters from Judson and O’Brien, were upon the aspects of Presidential-election canvassing. Major Roberdeau came to say that he should go to-morrow Morning for New-York— I sent to Brown’s Hotel, to be given him to-morrow Morning the answer to W. Duane’s offers of Service— B. O. Tyler came to borrow money; but I had none to lend him. Baron Stackelberg was at the Office to request an Exequatur for a Swedish Vice-Consul. Mr and Mrs Cutts were here this Eve. The War-Office and Treasury War continues to rage. There is a long reply to the Near Observer, in the Washington Republican of this Evening; and the City Gazette is filled with columns of abuse upon Mr Calhoun, and M’Kenney, and with republished Scraps against me— For it republishes from every Newspaper in the Union, every thing that appears in the shape of an attack upon me.

26. V:30. Rose and wrote by Candle-light— Letter to my son John— In the progress of retrieving the arrears of my Diary, I have reached the 20th. of July. There came a person calling himself Baron Plettenberg of Munster—a German, coarsely clad, and in deep indigence— A Westphalian Nobleman, who had served he told me several years in the armies of Napoleon, but came to this Country two years ago for subsistence, and wanting now to return to Europe for the same cause. Noblemen cannot in this Country find even subsistence— He enquired for the residence of the President, to which I gave him the direction. George’s Classmate Briggs left us, to return to Virginia. T. Cook was here to see Johnson Hellen— Force came, and brought me half a dozen copies of my book which is at length published— Visit from General Jessup, who has returned from Ohio married. Also from Samuel Harrison Smith, with a young kinsman of his from Georgia, named Bayard. At the Office, Mr Rodney, the Senator from Delaware called, to recommend the appointment of a Mr Reilly as Consul at Acapulco in Mexico; and mentioned the intention of Mr Warner to return to the Havanna— The President sent me a Letter from P. S. Duponceau of Philadelphia to General John Mason of Georgetown, informing him of a certain Mr Sanchez from the Havanna, recommended to Duponceau by a French Officer, who served in the late War, at New-Orleans, now at the Havanna— Sanchez comes as a secret Agent from a number of the principal inhabitants of the place, who have formed the plan of declaring the Island Independent of Spain, and are
desirous of being admitted as a State into the American Union— The object of the Mission of Mr Sanchez is to enquire if the Government of the United States will concur with them in that object. The plan is represented as already so far matured, that they want nothing but the assurance of being seconded from this Country to act immediately— The President desired that Duponceau’s Letter might be passed to Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt, and directed a meeting at his house to-morrow— Mrs Thornton was here this Evening— I played a game of chess with W. S. Smith.

27. V:45. Rain Storm— Received a Note from the President, calling the Meeting of the Members of the Administration, at One O’Clock. At the Office I found a despatch from R. Rush, with the information that on the 12th. of August, the Marquis of Londonderry, the British Secretary of State for foreign Affairs, committed suicide by cutting his throat with a small penknife— “With a bare Bodkin.” His mind was like the cable that drew up the frigate at the Navy-Yard, upon the inclined plane—stretched till it snapped— Attended at the President’s at one O’Clock— Mr Calhoun only was there, Mr Wirt being unwell, and not able to attend— The proposition of Mr Sanchez, as disclosed in Mr. Duponceau’s Letter to General Mason was discussed— There was also a second Letter, explanatory of the first and more strictly confidential. The question was discussed what was to be done. Mr Calhoun has a most ardent desire that the Island of Cuba should become a part of the United States, and says that Mr Jefferson has the same— There are two dangers, to be averted by that event. One that the Island should fall into the hands of Great-Britain; the other that it should be revolutionized by the Negroes— Calhoun says Mr Jefferson told him two years ago, that we ought at the first possible opportunity to take Cuba, though at the cost of a War with England; but as we are not now prepared for this, and as our great object must be to gain time, he thought we should answer this overture, by dissuading them from their present purpose, and urging them to adhere at present to their connection with Spain— I thought it advisable to take a different course— To give them no advice whatever— To say that the Executive of the United States is not competent to promise them admission as a State into the Union; and that if it were, the proposal is of a nature which our relations of amity with Spain would not permit us to countenance— Mr Calhoun suggested, that it would be proper for the President to make it a subject of a confidential communication to Congress, at their next Session; and he objected that if much stress should be laid upon our relations with Spain as forbidding our acceptance of the proposal, it might be considered as indirect instigation to the declaration of Independence, inasmuch as that would release us from the obligation of considering it as involving any of the rights of Spain— I replied that there would be no possibility of proceeding in the business by confidential Communication to Congress— First because there has not been one Message, with closed doors, during the present Administration; nor I believe since the Peace— The very notice of a secret Session would rouse an insatiate curiosity throughout the Nation to know, what could be its object— And secondly the proposal was of a nature which would not admit of secresy; the power of Congress itself to act upon it was questionable— It involved external War and internal revolution, in its essential and inevitable consequences— It would neither be possible nor proper that such business should be transacted by secret Sessions of Congress— The whole affair would be divulged in a week—perhaps in a day. All Europe, as well as America would have notice of it, and the very communication of the proposal to Congress as a subject for their deliberations by the President, might be taken by Spain as hostility to her, and give warning to Great-Britain, to take an immediate and determined stand against it. As to taking Cuba at the cost of a War
with Great-Britain, it would be well to enquire before undertaking such a War, how it would be likely to terminate; and for the present, and for a long time to come, I hold it for certain that a War with Great-Britain for Cuba, would result in her possession of that Island, and not ours. In the present relative situation of our maritime forces, we could not maintain a War against Great Britain for Cuba. Nor did I think that a plain distinct answer that our relations with Spain forbid our encouragement of a proposal to annex one of her Colonies to our own Union could be construed into an instigation to revolt. It was a reference to a plain principle of moral duty expressly applicable to the case; suitable to be acted upon as a motive, and honourable to the good faith of the Nation. I would give them at the same time to understand that the Government of the United States entertain the most friendly sentiments towards the inhabitants of Cuba; and are fully aware of the common interests which point to a most intimate connection between them and the United States— But to advise them to cling to their connection with Spain, would expose them to be transferred to Great-Britain by Spain, of which there is double danger, first by the present revolutionary Government of Spain to purchase support against the holy Alliance; and secondly by Ferdinand, to purchase the aid of Great-Britain to consummate a counter-revolution in his favour. Now by advising the People of Cuba to adhere to Spain, we expose them to both these dangers; and if the transfer should be made; they would charge the result upon us, and a heavy responsibility for the consequence would be upon us, for such ill-judged interposition— Mr Calhoun said he inclined to think there would be no immediate danger of a transfer of the Island to Great-Britain. The President directed an adjourned meeting for tomorrow— General Mason was at the President’s house, but not present at the Meeting— Johnson Hellen was confined to his bed with a severe fever.

28. VI. At the President’s; but Mr Wirt continues unwell, and the President directed the postponement of the adjourned meeting till Monday— I returned to him his written opinion upon the compensations and outfits to our Ministers abroad, and mentioned to him some inaccuracies of fact in relation to the case of Mr Clay, which he said he would rectify— He asked me if I thought there was any foundation for the claim of General Armstrong— I said I was not acquainted with the facts; but so far as I could judge, the only ground for Armstrong’s claim was the allowance lately made to Mr Clay— An objection to that in my mind which superseded all enquiry into its merits was that the account had been six or seven years settled, and that it was reopened, not upon any allegation of error, but to make a new and gratuitous allowance— That obstacle removed, I thought Mr Armstrong’s claim rested, upon the merits of the facts alleged by him—of which I had no knowledge. The President said that of the two pretensions of extra-service, one was for a voluntary and unnecessary interference with the proceedings of the Louisiana Convention Commission of Claims and the other for being joined in a Commission with Mr Bowdoin to negotiate with Spain which negotiation never took place— He asked me also to examine the Accounts of Mr Livingstone and of Mr Charles Pinckney to ascertain if any allowance was made to them for being joined in the Louisiana and Aranjuez Negotiations. The President said he intended to leave the City next Tuesday, to visit for about a fortnight his place in Albemarle County;
Virginia. Mr Frye was here this Evening— I walked home with him; and afterwards closed the Evening at Chess with Mr Smith.

29. VI: Received this Morning from the President, several Letters from Captain Spence of the Cyane, to the Secretary of the Navy, and a correspondence between Captain Spence and the Governor of Porto-Rico, relating to the privateers from that Island, and to the capture of one of them, by Lieutenant Gregory— These papers were to be passed to the other members of the administration— I immediately left them after perusal at Mr Calhoun’s house. Heard Mr Little, from Romans 11.7 “What then? Israel hath not obtained that which he seeketh for, but the election hath obtained it, and the rest were blinded.” A discourse upon predestination and universal Salvation— This doctrine though not necessarily connected with unitarianism, seems congenial with it. If benevolence be an attribute of the deity, and such is the theory of all Christian Sects, eternity of punishments is impossible— Eternity of punishment is not necessary to any purpose of divine Justice. It subserves no end— It cannot reform the offender— It cannot redress his wrongs. It is suffering inflicted for mere vengeance. It can never proceed from benevolence. Mr Little gave notice, that being himself unwell, there would be no afternoon service. I walked this Evening with Mr Smith and George to Mr Frye’s. I wrote this Evening to my wife, who from the 16th. of this month has been upon a visit at Mr Hopkinson’s at Bordentown.

30. VI:Mr G. Hadfield was here this morning, and brought his Power of Attorney to R. Rush, to be authenticated at the Department of State and forwarded to him. Mr Holley the President of the Transylvania University at Lexington, Kentucky, called for a moment; being on his way, returning with his family thither, after a summer visit to Boston. Baron Stackelberg called at the Office to ask for an Exequatur for a Swedish Vice-Consul; and to speak upon the claim that Norwegian Vessels should be admitted to import Articles other than of the growth produce or manufacture of Norway, without payment of any discriminating duties, because the Norwegian Ordinance admits vessels of the United States upon that footing into the Ports of Norway. We had repeatedly discussed this subject before and I had always told the Baron, as I now repeated that the Law of Congress did not admit of our going the full length of the Norwegian Ordinance— And I observed that no real reciprocity would result if it should. Sweden herself did not give us the benefit of the Norwegian Ordinance; and our exportations to Norway alone, must always be trifling and insignificant— Three or four vessels a year would carry all the merchandize for which Norway could furnish for us a market, and the proportion of Articles other than the produce of the United States, exported in them could be of no account— But if while by our necessary restrictions, conflicting with those of Great-Britain and France, our direct commerce with the British West Indies, and with France herself was nearly suspended, Norwegian Vessels could bring us all the Articles of importation from those Countries without payment of any discriminating duties, our countervailing restrictions would operate only against ourselves, and our Navigation Acts would prove altogether nugatory— The wishes of the United States were for the most liberal principles of commercial intercourse with all the world; but they could not adopt them with one Nation, while all the rest adhered to the system of restrictions, and of exclusions against them. Nor could Sweden claim them, in behalf of Norway, while she declined acceding to them herself, in her own intercourse with us. The Baron admitted that this was reasonable, and said he did not know why the Swedish Government had not extended the principle of the Norwegian Ordinance to Sweden itself. Mr Andrew Mitchell came to
urge me to report to the President upon his fathers accounts— I attended the Cabinet-Meeting at the President’s— Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt were there. The Letters from Duponceau to General Mason, and the proposals of Mr Sanchez were again discussed. The proposition is that the People of Cuba should immediately declare themselves Independent of Spain without any co-operation of the United States, and then ask admission to this Confederation as one of the States of the Union. By his first Letter, Duponceau had understood the offer to be that they should come in as Louisiana had been received— To be governed first as a territory, and afterwards admitted, as one or more States— The second Letter rectifies this error. They ask admission at once; as one State, with full interior Sovereignty of its own. I doubted the authority not only of the Executive, but of Congress to perform this— Mr Calhoun thought the case of Louisiana had settled the Constitutional question. But a transaction which should make an Island separated from this Continent by the Ocean, at once a member of the Union, with a Representation in both Houses of Congress, would certainly be an act of more transcendent power, than a mere purchase of territory contiguous to our own. I observed also that we had not sufficient foundation for presenting the proposal to Congress in any shape. We had nothing but Mr Sanchez’s word, that he had authority from anyone. We knew not from whom his authority came, nor how it had been given him— We knew not how far the project had been matured, nor what were its prospects of success. More information upon all this would be necessary before we could take a step of any kind in an affair of deeper importance and greater magnitude than had occurred since the Establishment of our Independence— It was concluded that the answer to Mr Sanchez must be negative, as to giving any encouragement to the Revolutionary movement; but Mr Calhoun still thought we should dissuade them from it. I observed that whatever answer we should give must be one, which we must be prepared to see divulged— We must not expect it will be kept secret; whatever General Mason writes to Duponceau, he will make known to Sanchez, and Sanchez to his Constituents whoever they may be— It is said that the project has been long in agitation, and is even much discussed publicly at the Havanna. The controul of the secret, will not be in our power, and even if it should be faithfully kept, we must answer as it if would not. There was a proposal that General Mason should separately answer each of Duponceau’s Letters—one for communication to Sanchez, as our answer, and the other as suggestions to be made to him through Duponceau, as from General Mason himself. I thought this would make no difference; so far as secrecy was the object whatever should go from the Government would be known to go from the Government, however enveloped in forms— Mr. Wirt made a short draft, of what he thought might be given to General Mason for an answer to Duponceau, which after some discussion the President said he would keep, and prepare a draft from it, to be considered to-morrow— I took an Evening walk and then played Chess with Smith.

Day— Distribution of time as the preceding Months; but morning baths have ceased since the 17th. and since the 21st. I have resumed this Diary, the arrears of which I have retrieved to the first of August, this day commenced— Since the 21st. also the Theatre has been closed, and as the Evenings lengthen and grow cool, I am enabled to employ a part of them in reading or writing. But more frequently at Chess.
